moves.1. e4: ~ A friendly between myself and another fellow community theatre player. Our First Round of three games, which saw me winning two-out-of-three.
moves.1... g6: Surprised he would concede the Centre so naively! Fianchetto soon?
moves.2... Bg7: Cutting across the major diagonal, but the Knights are still back.
moves.5. d4: Perhaps my Pawns are too far forward, but I like the domination of space I have here.
moves.5... O-O: An early decision to Castle, but poorly developed in my honest opinion.
moves.6. Bc4: It will be interesting to see how Black deals with pressure on this Knight.
moves.6... Nb6: So now both Knights are pushed into the perimeter. I'll maintain my Bishop.
moves.7. Bb3 d5: No desire to take the d-Pawn, here. I prefer the flood technique in the Middle.
moves.8. Nc3: Finally I get to push out another Horse.
moves.8... Bg4: The desire to clear out Pawns Kingside makes me feel comfortable with the Bishop pin. Black is not a threat to me right now.
moves.9. Be3: Getting the second Priest out of my way. But I don't have a role for him in this game.
moves.9... Nc4: Forked! I knew it was not a sound decision to move the Bishop that far. I will not exchange the Bishop for a Knight.
moves.10. Bf2 Nc6: I think I still have the advantage, but what I'm about to do with my light-squared Bishop is maddening!
moves.11. Ba4 Nxb2: Forked, Part II! What was I thinking?
moves.12. Qb1 Nxa4 13. Nxa4: I am down in material one Pawn. Yet I feel that I will be compensated.
moves.13... Bxf3: Doubling my Pawns, Black is so predictable!
moves.14. gxf3 f6: This next one could be a poison Pawn if Black plays it right.
moves.15. Qxb7 Na5: Perhaps the only choice? But it takes the Knight out of the fight. A Knight on the rim is grim.
moves.16. Qa6: e6's Square is tempting me! This could be the break I am looking for.
moves.16... c5: Blunder! I can finally cause chaos. 16 ... c6 would not have afforded me this chance.
moves.17. Qe6+: Black should retreat the King to h8!
moves.17... Rf7: Pin! Now my Knight is back in the battle.
moves.18. Nxc5: Will Black offer a exchange of Queens?
moves.19... fxe5: Trying to get compensation for the lost material, but it allows me to break up my Doubled-Pawns along the f-File.
moves.20. fxe5 Qf8: Black's Queen is sliding laterally along the Back Rank.
moves.21. Ne6: Now Black is finally forked, obvious choice is to spare the Queen.
moves.21... Qc8 22. Nxg7: With a pinned-Rook, only the King can capture.
moves.22... Kxg7 23. Qxa5: And the forgotten Knight pays the price.
moves.23... Qxc2: At this point I stand to lose some Pawns.
moves.24. O-O: Perhaps I am Castling to early. Or too late.
moves.24... Rxf3: I should have managed my Bishops better in this match.
moves.25. Rac1 Qf5 26. Rc7: A decision to attack aggressively almost cost me in this game. I have chosen the f7 Square to focus my power, and Black chooses f1.
moves.27... Rxf2: A kind of Alekhine's gun. We'll call it Joseph's gun. He almost makes a thrilling comeback, seizing my Bishop and threatening Mate.
moves.28. Rxe7+: My one move left! I hope he blocks with the Rook. If Kh8, then it's over. I would be trapped.
moves.29... Qxf7: Of course we'll exchange! I have more Pawns!
moves.30. Qxf7+ Rxf7: And my Rooks have X-Ray Eyes! :P
moves.31. Rxf7+ Kxf7 32. Kf2 Ke6 33. Ke3: I win the footrace to my back Pawn!
moves.34... a5 35. a4: Locking up the Queenside, to complete the Zugzwang.
moves.35... Kd5: Combinational Chess Theory. I don't see a way for Black to win. I can kill off Pawns on either side of the Board with my King, while promoting to Queen before Joseph.
